title: Participation in the Half Time Scholars podcast
text:
On this episode, I spoke about my PhD research on the stereotypical framing of migrants and refugees in media coverage comparing Brazil and the United Kingdom (UK).






Episode based on my dissertation



During my PhD, I have published four different papers on migration framing. You can find the full details of the papers below the episode.



 

Dissertation Papers


Gonçalves, I., & David, Y. (2025). Threats, victims, or heroes? Media frames about migration in the United Kingdom and Brazil. International Communication Gazette, 87(3). https://doi.org/10.1177/17480485241249007.


Gonçalves, I. (2024). Promoting hate speech by dehumanizing metaphors of immigration. Journalism Practice, 18(2), 265–282. https://doi.org/10.1080/17512786.2023.2212661.


Gonçalves, I. (2024). Sources and framing: How the citation of different actors predicts the tone of representation on migration issues. Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies. https://doi.org/10.1080/1369183X.2023.2227346.


Gonçalves, I., & David, Y. (2022). A systematic literature review of the representations of migration in Brazil and the United Kingdom [Una revisión sistemática de la literatura de las representaciones de la migración en Brasil y Reino Unido]. Comunicar, 71. https://doi.org/10.3916/C71-2022-04.

title: Isabella Gonçalves
text:
email
  
  
    
     CV
  

  
  
I am a postdoctoral researcher at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz, where my work focuses on digital political communication and journalism studies. Alongside my research, I serve as editor of the Political Communication Report and manage the websites and social media channels for the Political Communication divisions of APSA and ICA. I am also an active member of the DigiWorld network and the Digital Media and Society Observatory. I have expertise in data analysis, mixed-methods research, and project management.
My research examines the structural and discursive factors that contribute to the establishment and reinforcement of social divisions. I focus on issues such as divisive and negative political discourse, the underrepresentation of marginalized groups in digital political communication and legacy news media, and journalism safety.
Research interests: political communication, journalism studies, journalism safety, othering of outgroups, divisive issues in public discourse.

title: Participation in the Let’s Talk About Politics and Governance Podcast
text:
Crises have deepened political divisions, and social media has amplified these tensions. In this podcast, I explain our paper examining Facebook posts from recent elections in Brazil, Colombia, Chile, and Peru. I show a trend in this episode: divisive topics ignite strong, often negative reactions, particularly in countries with high levels of political polarization.






Episode based on a published research paper:



Divisive Issues, Polarization, and Users’ Reactions on Facebook: Comparing Campaigning in Latin America
By Vicente Fenoll, Isabella Gonçalves, and Márton Bene

title: Researcher in the project BOTO – The Amazon WhatsApp Bot
text:
BOTO is an innovative tool created by InfoAmazonia that delivers content about the Amazon region directly to audiences on WhatsApp, using artificial intelligence (AI) to make access to reliable, contextualized, and personalized information easier.
This WhatsApp bot combines journalism, innovation, and technology to offer an informative experience tailored to each user, promoting awareness and engagement with the challenges facing the Amazon.
InfoAmazonia’s WhatsApp bot combines journalism, innovation, and technology to offer an informative experience tailored to each user, promoting awareness and engagement with the challenges facing the Amazon.
Knowledge about the Amazon can—and should—be within everyone’s reach! With BOTO, you can stay informed, understand, share, and take action—all from your phone.






My role in Research:



I participated in this project as part of the research team. Using value-sensitive design, we identified the values desired by stakeholders in a technology of this kind to support its development. To this end, we collected data through focus groups with the audience of InfoAmazonia. These findings informed the creation of the WhatsApp bot. The research had two goals: first, to contribute to the bot’s development; and second, to advance scholarship on the use of generative AI in journalism.
